Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Understanding the Connections Between Economics Behaviors

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
This award funds research in behavioral economics that will analyze the possible relationships between economic behaviors using new data and new modeling methods.

Over the past thirty years, behavioral and experimental economists have made great strides in identifying behaviors that are hard to explain using the classic model of economic decision making: these include violations of expected utility theory such as the Allais paradox, ambiguity aversion, present bias, loss aversion and the endowment effect. All of these behaviors have been shown to affect important economic decisions, and have been the subject of enormous amounts of attention by researchers. However, far less attention has been paid to the links between these behaviors. This project examines these links both empirically and theoretically.

The first part of the project employs a laboratory experiment to measure a long list of well-known behavioral phenomena, including the ones listed above, in a single group of subjects, allowing the researchers to estimate the empirical relationship between them. Using these data they are then able to test the predictions of existing models about these relationships, and can use these results to guide their theoretical model. The second project develops part of that model, through a link between two particular behavioral biases: the Allais paradox in choice over risky prospects (i.e. where the probabilities of different outcomes are known) and the Ellsberg paradox in choice over uncertain prospects (i.e. where the probabilities of different outcomes are not known). Both behaviors can be explained by a unique behavioral axiom -- a generalized preference for hedging. This model will potentially be helpful in understanding behavior in environments that have both risk and uncertainty (such as financial decision making) and to capture more precisely the agent's attitude towards each of them. The third project extends the empirical work from project 1 by repeating the same experiment with a different subject pool, focusing on: (1) a representative sample of the US population; (2) subjects who suffer from anxiety and depression; (3) subjects primed into various emotional states.

Because the economic behaviors studied in this project are so ubiquitous, this grant could have a wide impact in many areas of the social sciences. For macroeconomists, who have long understood the impact of these biases on economic performance, understanding the relationship between them is necessary for understanding the distribution of economic outcomes. For policy makers, an understanding of any common cause to these biases could prove to be very helpful for any attempt to rectify them. For neuroeconomists and psychologists, such an understanding could aid the search for the biological bases of economic behavior.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the past 30 years, behavioral and experimental economists have made great strides in identifying robust phenomena that are hard to explain within the classic model of economic choice. Experiments show that people exhibit exceptionally high discount rates (between present and future rewards), and risk aversion (when choosing between sure and uncertain alternatives), as well many other violations of the canonical model such as ‘loss aversion’, ‘present bias’, the ‘endowment effect;’ and the behavioral paradoxes suggested by Allais and Ellsberg.  These behaviors have been shown to be important in many important economic settings, including financial markets, labor markets and savings decisions. These results have been largely responsible for the emergence of behavioral economics as an important approach to studying economic problems. At the same time, each of these findings has generated its own theoretical literature, leading to a bewildering array of models, each designed to capture a particular phenomenon.

 

The work of this grant has been to understand the links between these different behaviors, and in particular to study and test models which unify some or all of these phenomena as resulting from the same underlying process. We see this as an important step towards the development of parsimonious `workhorse' model of economic decision making, which is capable of capturing a variety of important behaviors in a parsimonious way. The development of such generalized models is of paramount importance for the lessons of behavioral economics to be further integrated with the rest of the profession.

 

Using the resources provided by the grant, our first aim was to construct a data set which measured a set of 11 behavioral economic phenomena in a group of 190 subjects. This allowed us to perform the simple but important task of checking which of these behaviors are correlated with each other across subjects. There are many possible theoretical links between behavioral economic phenomena. At the same time, there is no point in developing theoretical models that tie different behaviors to the same underlying parameters if these behaviors are not, in fact, related. Our data set can help to guide theoretical efforts by uncovering empirical links between different behaviors, as well as identifying those that are not related. Our results document strong correlations between some of these phenomena. Some of the correlations we document are predicted by existing models, like a link between loss aversion and the endowment effect; some were not predicted, like the link between ambiguity aversion and overconfidence; others were predicted by existing models, but we do not find them in our data, like a link between violations of Expected Utility and present bias. We also find little relation between intelligence or personality measures and economic behavior.

 

 

Based in part on the results of this experimental exercise, the grant helped us to complete a large number of theoretical and experimental projects that examined specific connections between certain behaviors. A third has used experimental labor market data to look at the relationship between random choice and a preference for contracts which provide a large number of alternatives to choose from.
